column5: My parents often talk about how much safer it was to be a kid at their age, I‚Äôve always thought that maybe they were a little blind to the privilege they had as white kids

Yeah. Part of the problem is that our brains are very good at patterns of behavior. So at some point we were in a stressful situation, and in classic fight/flight/freeze response we chose flight (or freeze), and it worked! It got us out of that situation!

So obviously our brains were like ‚Äúwell, this worked, let‚Äôs apply it to more situations‚Äù, and that‚Äôs very helpful in some cases! Things like dangerous situations or people that are toxic are good to avoid. But then we start applying it to more and more things, and it becomes a problem. It becomes our go-to solution and it‚Äôs very hard to train oneself out of a habit, especially when that habit is actually not doing something.

There‚Äôs no real easy solution to this other than taking it day by day, and trying to retrain yourself. It will always be easier to avoid things that you might fail at, but remember that that‚Äôs not healthy or good for you. You‚Äôre brain is kinda like a misbehaving dog, unfortunately. And retraining it is hard, but it is possible!

It doesn‚Äôt really make it look bad though... I thought it was a painting at first! Kinda pretty.

I can‚Äôt give you advice about your family, but you may want to limit your contact with news media so that you don‚Äôt have to interact with the state of the world as often. Sometimes ‚Äúignorance is bliss‚Äù translates into ‚Äúwillful ignorance for the moment is better for your mental health‚Äù

Do you have anyone you can lean on emotionally? Sometimes just having someone to vent to can help lessen the emotional toll of everything. Also if you have a piece of media or something that you really love or brings you good feelings, don‚Äôt hesitate to indulge in it.

Right now your mental health is more important than ‚Äústaying informed‚Äù, don‚Äôt feel bad for making decisions that prioritize that!

My brother is very much the same way. A lot of the time he just doesn‚Äôt think to reply to stuff I send him, unless it‚Äôs obv a question I need him to answer. Luckily he has read repceits (that isn‚Äôt spelled right sorry) on so I know that he at least is reading what I send him, which is enough of a compromise for me.

That being said it would be a totally different story if it was my boyfriend pulling that crap. Being in a relationship is a choice he made and you‚Äôre not something he can neglect without consequences.

On the other hand, does your bf struggle with anxiety or depression (or something like that) at all? I only ask because when my anxiety gets really bad I have a tendency to isolate and not return texts or calls and ignore people. It doesn‚Äôt really excuse him, but that would make it more understandable and something he can work on.
This sounds like something you may need to bring up to a vet. It may be something neurological or just a behavioral thing you don‚Äôt know about.

I feel like your ‚Äúrough edges‚Äù might actually be more helpful in connecting with possible clients (patients??) than you think. My dad was a doctor (retired now) who dressed and acted in a very ‚Äúunprofessional‚Äù manner and many people actually found that they liked him more than other doctors who were more professional and serious. A lot of people complained about having to go to his partners when he retired because they liked him more! As long as you have the knowledge and will to help people the rest shouldn‚Äôt be a problem.

Remember that even if this fails, you already have skills and experience you can fall back on! True that you probably can‚Äôt get your job back right away with the pandemic and all, but it won‚Äôt last forever! My only concern is that you may not both want to switch what you‚Äôre doing at the same time so that one of you has some stability while the other get settled.


Add on: I‚Äôve hated almost every ‚Äúclassic‚Äù/‚Äúprofessional‚Äù therapist I‚Äôve been to and if you were going into regular therapy I‚Äôd totally want to at least give you a chance. Sometimes the classic mold doesn‚Äôt work and it‚Äôs good to have a change!

They might get a notice that someone tried to log on to their email, but since you didn‚Äôt get on it shouldn‚Äôt be a big deal. They will probably just change their password at the most.

I‚Äôm pretty sure it doesn‚Äôt give them your IP address or anything, so I don‚Äôt think you have to worry about getting in trouble.

Remember that depression will lie to you and encourage you to cut off contact from people. I can‚Äôt say for sure either way but remember that he is his own person who can make his own choices.

Do you have a therapist you can talk this out with? Talking it out with a professional may help clear up whether your concerns are right or if your brain is lying to you.

Tbh this probably isn‚Äôt something that is specific to your school, several colleges will cover up things like sexual assault and hazing and other things that are awful. I know this is especially prevalent in rich and private colleges as well.

That being said you should certainly exercise some caution! I would consider some things like taking a self defense class, getting some pepper spray just in case. I know there‚Äôs a self defense thing you can put on your keychain that looks like an abstract cat face and works kinda like spiked knuckles (google ‚Äúwomen‚Äôs self defense weapons‚Äù for more ideals)

And obviously watch any drinks and don‚Äôt let anyone pour you a drink, always pour your own! And be careful who you trust.

If it really bothers you I suggest bringing your concerns up with your family. They may have more ideas or be able to see how valid your concerns are better since they know where you‚Äôre going

This is very hard. I would hate to think that years of friendship might not even be real. Hopefully it‚Äôs simply out of a place of concern for your soul (or whatever you believe) and not whatever righteous crap would lead someone to fake being friends with you.

That being said, the best advice I can give if you want to avoid confrontation is to simply stonewall any talks of religion. When he brings it up just be like ‚Äúthat‚Äôs nice‚Äù and then change the conversation. Just straight up don‚Äôt give him any ammunition to continue the conversation down that path. Either he‚Äôll get the hint and let up or he‚Äôll confront you/distance himself which will let you know he wasn‚Äôt your friend in the first place.

Maybe try hanging out with people more like yourself? Idk but it sounds like you end up around a lot of people that suck, so maybe it‚Äôs your environment you need to change? I don‚Äôt really go out much so I don‚Äôt have any specific advice though, sorry.

I‚Äôm not an expert on anything but if the contract reads as legit, and the only thing you‚Äôre risking is a video, then I don‚Äôt see why not.
However! Do keep a copy of the signed contract! Maybe 2. That way if they try to forge your signature on anything or ‚Äúlose‚Äù the contract you will have the copy to hold against them.

I‚Äôm not super educated on this but maybe just looking up how to deal with phobias in kids will help with some ideas?
Other than that I guess try having the fan on during the day some? If she gets used to it she might relax. Also if it‚Äôs the noise that bothers her you might try playing soft music or white noise from your phone/computer so she doesn‚Äôt have to hear it?
I was afraid of a lot of things as a kid and eventually I‚Äôd just have to deal with it or find a way around it (or give myself ocd but that‚Äôs unrelated to this), but I understand there‚Äôs no real way for you to do that when you‚Äôre not the one with the fear, so I‚Äôm not totally sure what other advice might help

Tbh I‚Äôm not sure what you can do about it now, but if he does it again you should definitely confront him while he‚Äôs in your yard. He may just think it‚Äôs not a big deal or not think to ask before going on your property? Though that sounds unrealistic if you have a fence.

It‚Äôs natural to want the love of your family, especially your parents. Don‚Äôt ever feel bad for wanting to love someone! However this doesn‚Äôt mean you should put up with toxic behavior or abuse. It might be a good idea to keep some record of the things she has done to remind yourself of why you chose to split off away from her.

If she changes her behavior then by all means you can build a relationship with her, but don‚Äôt put yourself into a toxic relationship out of hope that she will change when you‚Äôve seen no evidence of it.

Do you have any reason to think someone is threatening your family? If not then I‚Äôd just clean it up for now, but keep an eye out for anything else that seems weird like that in the next couple weeks (and keep photographic evidence!)

Maybe try starting off small? Things like hand holding or leaning on someone‚Äôs shoulder. It might help even to explain to other people what you‚Äôre trying to do so that a) they understand and b) you have more control over the situation.

Also, I don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôve ever heard of this thing called love languages? The basic idea behind it is that love and affection can be communicated in different ways, and much like languages or taste what works for one person may not commute to another. The feeling of affection and happiness you‚Äôre looking for may not be something you can find in touch, but that doesn‚Äôt mean you can‚Äôt find it elsewhere! I highly recommend looking it up because it‚Äôs very interesting and informative even if it doesn‚Äôt help with exactly what you‚Äôre asking.
There might be a scar. If it really bothers you you can get some scar removal cream to lesson it, but I‚Äôd wait until it heals all the way first to see how it looks!

Remember that the first thing you‚Äôve instinctually thought is usually what you‚Äôve been taught to think, and come up with ways to combat that.

Some things that help are positive thinking, which is obv what it sounds like. If you can‚Äôt do that then even just neutral thinking is fine. Things like ‚Äúmy body gets me from place to place‚Äù and ‚Äúmy body works and does what it needs to‚Äù are still better than negative thoughts!

I know some people will also assign a name or person to their bad thoughts to separate themselves from them and combat them. For instance I‚Äôve heard of one girl who, whenever she has a self deprecating thought, pretends it‚Äôs Trump who said it and then she goes ‚Äúshut up, Trump‚Äù (obv insert whoever you don‚Äôt like instead idk this isn‚Äôt the spot for politics)

And make sure you get a support group! Even just some people online who you can turn to and share your struggles with is better than not having anyone!

Maybe ask your therapist for some resources that can help educate your boyfriend. I‚Äôve had a similar issue with my mom and I eventually just had to learn to ignore her/hide certain things from her. Sometimes the people that care about us don‚Äôt actually know how best to care for us, and even if/when we forgive them for that it doesn‚Äôt make it any easier.

You may want to look into stim toys and other things that can be used in place of those urges. I‚Äôm not sure what all is out there or if it will help but it can‚Äôt hurt to try! If nothing else you can get gloves to wear to stop yourself from scratching.

You may also want to look into getting some medication. It sounds like this interferes with your life often and frequently enough that it is difficult to function normally, which is pretty much what medications were made to help with!

Depending on what your parents are like (and how big/noticeable the scar is) you might be able to get away with something like ‚Äúidk where it came from‚Äù and just acting really confused. (I have a couple small scars that idk where they actually came from) You could try to act like it was always there and just hope they don‚Äôt address it, but it sounds like you don‚Äôt think that will work. There might be some water proof something you can cover it with (makeup or body paint?) but that‚Äôs kind of a lot of trouble and (at least for makeup) maybe expensive.

There is scar remover cream you can use! It won‚Äôt completely get rid of it but it should make it less noticeable.

If you really want you can try the ‚ÄúI tripped and it wasn‚Äôt that big of a deal at the time‚Äù sort of thing? Like you weren‚Äôt actively trying to hide anything it just wasn‚Äôt a big enough deal to bother anyone with.

You may eventually just have to come clean in the end tbh, but once you‚Äôve done that it‚Äôs finished and you won‚Äôt have to worry about it anymore!

Do you have any of her contact info? Like Facebook or twitter or a cell number? You said your brother worked for the aunts bf so maybe you could get some contact info through him?

I went through a similar thing with one of my cousins, but I was immensely lucky to run into her again on accident one day and reconnect some. It‚Äôs immensely wonderful just having the knowledge that I can talk to her again! I hope everything goes well with you two!

Thank you! I have the bad habit of wanting to help people get through the same things I am struggling with, only to discover that, wow, I don‚Äôt have the answers or words to help because I am also struggling with that very thing, so it‚Äôs very helpful to hear what other people have to say

If she is at risk then I would definitely advise wearing a mask! However that doesn‚Äôt mean all affection has to be tabled! Hugs from behind (so you aren‚Äôt breathing on each other) should be ok, and physical affection should be good after you shower I imagine. If you move your shower time to after you get home from work you might be able to be close then? (You‚Äôd probably still have to wear a mask, and def you should change clothes, also I‚Äôm not a doctor)

These times really suck in terms of wanting to be close to people when you can‚Äôt be, but it‚Äôs worth the sacrifice to make sure our loved ones stay safe! But there are still ways for contact if you need it that shouldn‚Äôt put her at excess risk. I hope you both stay healthy and safe!
Yeah I was gonna say ‚Äúidk but if you get a good answer let me know!‚Äù Because oof same üòî

I‚Äôm probably not the best advice for this (I‚Äôm not great at social situations either), but something I try to do is just kind of... be present in people‚Äôs conversations? Like don‚Äôt ease-drop but be physically there and pay attention to what they‚Äôre saying. Then when there‚Äôs a bit of a lull try adding something to the convo.

I know that was pretty vague, but this is one of those things that takes practice more than anything to get the hang of, unfortunately.

It also helps to look positive and interested in what other people are saying, even if you‚Äôre feeling excluded and like you can‚Äôt take part in the conversation. That‚Äôs more of just a psychological/body language thing I have heard around than something I have tried enough to confirm though.

No that‚Äôs definitely valid! They are not only putting themselves at risk but also their children, and considering that perfectly healthy young people have died from this it‚Äôs absurd that they do that.

These are very valid concerns to have! Music is wonderful but I do know the field is very competitive no matter what you do with it. If you really feel passionate about music I would definitely try to go for that in your future, but make sure to have a backup plan! Have maybe a list of things you‚Äôre good (or at least decent) at that you can pursue as a main career if music doesn‚Äôt work out. Remember you can always pursue music as a hobby or on your own even if you don‚Äôt end up working in it!

I do want to ask, though: are you planning on getting a higher education? If you are then that gives you some extra time to find what you want to do with your life and what you think will work. It is also a great place to form connections and ‚Äúnetwork‚Äù, which can be very helpful when looking for jobs!
